This is the game after which the Warriors, rather than continuing to battle Cleveland, a fair fight, the Warriors call on Kevin Durant to join them. Kevin, a free agent agreed to join a 73-9 team to chase rings. How the NBA allowed the trade to go through is perplexing to say the least. The Warriors get a top two or three shooter in the league and Cleveland is playing with an injured Kevin Love and injured Kyrie Irving out for the season! And Cleveland features Matthew Delavadova at guard while LBJ has zero help, to face a Kevin Durant led Warriors team. This is where I realize that the NBA is a bit shady for allowing this trade to go through. Remember, the NBA had stopped the Chris Paul trade saying it wasnâ€™t good for the league. Yes, but then they allow a 73-9 team to trade for Durant. Yes, the NBA is a bit shady and has favorites! If you think not, just look how they allow an already stacked roster in Boston to go and get the best defensive guard in the game, plus Porzingus, another all star center, just so Boston can get a chip,because Boston failed to get past the Warriors and a lowly Miami team for two seasons. Yes, the NBA is a bit shady, all imo. ğŸ˜‚

I donâ€™t think weâ€™ll ever see another NBA Finals that will top this one. Just the story line itself. 73-9 team. Clear favorites take a 3-1 lead and look prime to win it again. God still to this day I canâ€™t believe the Cavs won. I was born and raised in Cleveland Ohio and rooted for the Cavs before these finals and I root for them still till this day. This is one of those games that you remember exactly where you were at, I was at my grandmas house and my eyes were glued to the tv while I sat in front of it on the floor . I remember being so nervous and scared that the Cavs were going to lose again because when they lost in 2015 I was devastated so I knew this year we had to win. I and everyone else watching witnessed history live, but as someone who actually is from Cleveland and suffered the lost throughout the years, seeing them finally win our first championship in any sport since 1964 was amazing. I remember the block, the shot, Kevin Loves defense on Curry, LeBronâ€™s free throw and the sound of the buzzer going off better than the back of my hand. When LeBron had that iconic block on Iguodala I screamed of joy and when Kyrie hit that game winning 3 I started to celebrate but I was still terrified, until we were up by 4 points with 10.6 seconds left of the game. The Warriors had the ball with 10.6 seconds left of the the game and Cleveland was up by 4 it was at that moment I knew the Cavs won their first ever NBA championship. The Cavs were the underdogs and they were going against a 73-9 team, no one though they couldâ€™ve came back from a 3-1 lead but as a Cavs fan I knew that the could do it and I believed in them. This game was more than just basketball. This game was history, the first team in NBA history to comeback from a 3-1 lead in the finals, the Cavs first ever NBA championship, Clevelandâ€™s first championship in 52 years and it was the best night of my life. I remember when the clock ran out and the buzzer went off I started to celebrate and jump around, I poured water and beer on me just because how happy I was and I didnâ€™t know what to do. I remember the day after I had to check my phone and see if the Cavs actually won and I was so happy that it wasnâ€™t a dream. To me as a Cavs fan this made LeBron the Goat, he did something no one else ever did. He came back after 4 years and told Ohio that he was going to give us a championship and he sure did. This game made me respect LeBron as a player and person forever and he will always be the GOAT in my eyes. When LeBron left Cleveland in 2018 I wasnâ€™t mad because he gave us a championship like he said he was going to do. In fact when LeBron left I was a big LeBron fan by then and I told my self wherever LeBron goes I go and rooted for him ever since despite heâ€™s not on Cleveland anymore. When Kyrie left Cleveland in 2017 I wasnâ€™t mad because I was great full for what he did for the Cavs and the city and state of Cleveland, Ohio. I also have too much respect for Kyrie and I root for him and his team to this day. Kevin Love is amazing and I will always support him as well. Also I have to thank the Warriors for choking and blowing a 3-1 lead, seriously I really appreciate that. And in wise words of LeBron James â€œCLEVELAND THIS IS FOR YOU!â€

When LeBron retires we will really miss watching him play. Of course nobody will ever match Jordan's mythical aura of winning but what LeBron has done has been legendary. I always wished that LBJ would of had a coach like Phil Jackson or PoP. He went to 7 straight finals I believe and faced some very tough competition and legendary performances like vs Dirk and the Mavs. LBJ didn't have a Jerry Krause or Phil Jackson his whole career though he did have Riley who helped him win back to back titles. We are gonna look back at the LeBron era and have alot of great memories. Plus he seems like a genuinely good person. I hope he can get one more title before he retires but I doubt it. Well, I've got a feeling that my Lone Wolf boyfriend and SmackDown tag partner will probably be here soon. I probably should let Commissioner Silver know to be expecting him. I feel bad for you right now, knowing that you're going to have to drive home in an insane amount of traffic due to the celebration taking place in Cleveland that I'm sure will soon be extending to the entirety of Ohio itself. AJ: Yeah. I'm sure it's going to be insane by the time I get back home. Baron: I thought your friend was very decent, my Lone Wolfess. Ninja: Yeah. AJ: Wait. (turns toward the Lone Wolf.) You actually met Commissioner Silver? Baron: Yeah. I guess my Lone Wolfess told him to be expecting me. A while later in Las Vegas during Money In The Bank... AJ Hawk: (pulls up to the arena.) Alright, guys. I think this is where the both of you get off. Both: (exit the car.) Queen Madame Ninja Barrett: (with the inaugural Curse Breaker MVP trophy in her possession.) Alright. Thanks, Hawk. Just be careful getting home. AJ: Okay. (drives away.) Baron Corbin: Alright. Now, let's get inside and finish the Money In The Bank pay per view. Ninja: Of course, mi amor. I think I kept my Shield brothers waiting long enough. Both: (enter the arena.) Ninja: (takes the WWE World Heavyweight Championship.) Alright. Let's do this. Here. (gives the Lone Wolf her inaugural Curse Breaker MVP trophy.) Would you mind running that into my black metallic kingdom locker room for me while I take care of my Shield brothers? Compared to how teams play now in 2020 these warriors are chumps. Itâ€™s crazy to see that they really were just the first team to start taking advantage of the 3. The warriors dynasty is nothing more than them abusing the numerical advantage they had by taking a bunch of 3s while the rest of the league still relied on 2s. The entire league plays in the style of these warriors now. Itâ€™s like what the rockets tried doing with small ball but with the complete opposite outcome. The fact this experimental team was able to beat James and Irving in their prime along with changing the entire culture of the nba is legendary. The warriors put a huge dent on Lebronâ€™s legacy in 2015 as it he now had lost his first trip to the finals in every team he played for. In 2016 as an experimental team relying on odds rather than talent they choked after being up 3-1. In 2017 KD decided to single handily destroy Lebronâ€™s planned narrative of surpassing Michael Jordan in championships just by joining the warriors. In 2018 the GSW gave lebron his 6th NBA loss and his second sweep in the playoffs. Officially making him the only player to ever get swept in the playoffs in two different decades.  In 2019 lebron ran away from Cleveland and finally joined the lakers after saying he would never leave Cleveland... again. He then missed about 20 games and somehow failed to make the finals with a team that had more talent than the team he took to the 2018 finals. The Lakers ended up with the exact same record they had the year prior to him arriving here. When lebron realized he could not win on his own he stopped embarrassing himself and started recruiting Anthony Davis. In 2020 the Lakers traded almost their entire team to the New Orleans pelicans who suspiciously won the 1st pick the next year. (ğŸ˜‰ right Adam silver? ) Anthony Davis then proceeded to have an amazing season leading the Lakers in every stat except assist yet Lebron almost won MVP because of how hard the media drives his narrative.  In the 2020 NBA finals Jimmy Butler finally showed Lebron James what itâ€™s takes to win a championship thanks to hard work and determination instead of special treatment and shortcuts. What a wonderful world we live in â˜ºï¸

Yes, the Cavs were the better team. I'll provide you the context for this (i'll try to make it as short as i can, sorry if it's too long).   This was the 2nd iteration of one of Lebron's superteams immediately after leaving his last one (Miami Heat or Heatles) because DeWayne Wade and Chris Bosh were aging and their production was starting to decrease. So Lebron went back to Cleveland to join Kyrie (Kyrie was averaging 21 points per game and was an all star) and Kevin Love (was averaging 26 points per game and 12 rebounds per game and also was an all star). *All stars are NBA players that are exceptional in a statistical category (generally scoring).  This gets largely overlooked because Lebron has a HUGE fanbase (probably the biggest of the millenial and Gen Z generations) and the media pretty much has adored him for over a decade by this point. So what Lebron's fanbase will do to make this not seem like a superteam is try to diminish his teammates by saying things like "they've never been to the playoffs" or "they were only doing good because they were playing on a bad team". As if that removes their talent and abilities. What does tend to happen with Lebron's superteam formula though, is that the Power Forward's (Chris Bosh & Kevin Love) scoring average gets reduces because Lebron partially takes over their role and turns them into spot up shooters. Power forwards tend to like to be closer to the rim to score and rebound. The guards are the secondary scorers generally (DeWayne Wade & Kyrie Irving)  As for this series, the only reason the Warriors had this series in their favor was because Kevin Love had a concussion (Kevin Love was a part of the core group of the Cavs). So instead of it being Lebron, Kyrie and Kevin Love, it was Lebron, Kyrie and Kevin Love who was at 25% of himself due to playing with a concussion for the series. The tandem of Kyrie and Lebron outscored Klay and Steph both times they played in a 7 games series against each other. Had Love never gotten that concussion, this series never goes the way it did as evidenced by Love's performance in the following 2 finals series.

Take me back to June 19, 2016... the greatest day of my life. Nine-year-old (and 3/4) me had witnessed true greatness that day. Earlier that day I had made some Scratch project and it got on the front page, I don't even know anymore, but needless to say, it was already a good day.    Now during the Finals game, I'm half-playing on a Minecraft server discussing the game, and half-watching said game.   I shut off my Minecraft game for this series, and boy, oh boy was it worth it. I was locked in at that point. That was the start of Quarter 4. I was watching the whole game, but I couldn't just multitask anymore.  Fast forward. 100% attention on the game. iPod on the kitchen counter. Entire family in the living room, no contact with the internet. Whatever happens, happens, And then, James hits a three. The game is tied,  89-89.    And it stays that way for two whole minutes, until...   "Rebound taken by Iguodala!" "Iguodala to Curry, Back to Iguodala.."  I think to myself... Oh no. It's always right when i focus all of my attention that things fall apart...  But then...  "Up for the layup--OH! BLOCKED BY JAMES! LEBRON JAMES WITH THE REJECTION!!"  My heart skips a beat and my legs collapse in pure amazement. I had just witnessed something superhuman. It had to have been God, disguised as LeBron James. No. This was real life.  Under 60 seconds after getting back up on my two feet, Kyrie is 1-on-1 with Curry. He's hesitating. He's going to go for that three. To quote Richard Jefferson from his Players' Tribune article, we had basically shared the same thoughts at that moment:  ... He's gonna ...  ... wait, is he gonna?  ... Oh f*** he's really gonna.  ... Oh f*** that went in!!!!!!!  Not just a three. A fadeaway three. There go my knees again, but this time, I fell backwards onto the couch. Stunning. Unbelievable. Clutch.   If anyone could make that shot, it was Kyrie, and only Kyrie. Call me crazy, but if I had a Finals MVP vote, it would have gone to Kyrie Irving. Kyrie. Irving.  The man whose name I'd recognized only from some old Cocoa Pebbles commercial a few years back when I'd started watching NBA basketball. I don't know why I knew that. But I can safely say that I ate Cocoa Pebbles every day for the following week after those finals.   But if we're going to talk names, I will not let you forget about Kevin Love. Ten seconds after Kyrie's game-winning shot.   "Steph was trying to get open like his life was on the line, and Kevin was guarding him like his life was on the line."   Ten seconds of lockdown defense later, Curry would brick a three. That was what sealed the game... and the series... and the season... and basketball immortality. Forty seconds later, it ends.   "It's over! It's over! Cleveland is a city of champions once again! The Cavaliers are NBA champions!"  Fifty-two years of torment, and anguish... ...had been washed away.  That was it. The peak. The happiest I'd ever been. The happiest I'd ever be. Ever since, I have yet to feel happiness on a level even close to what I'd felt that night. It was something else. It was a miracle. It was magical.  It will always be cherished. And it will never be forgotten.   Because there will never ever be another Finals like it.

In terms of real star talent, Cavaliers was the most loaded team in the NBA. On paper, they were the best team in terms of talent. Anyone who thinks otherwise is really silly.    Warriors had a better team system and great chemistry. A legit championship quality team. But their loss to the Cavaliers isn't some sort of miracle, the Cavaliers had more than enough talent to win. Especially when Bogut got hurt, left the Warriors without a consistent rim protector. Draymond's suspension was a critical momentum swinger too, it created a lot of doubt and mental fatigue for the Warriors for game 5.    Once the Cavaliers took game 5, they had momentum on their side to win the next 2 games. Kyrie/Bron could attack the paint at will without Bogut in the rotation.

I'm sure Kyrie was celebrating here too they just didn't show him as much due to all of the above factors.

I rank Lebron over Jordan since sometime during the 2016-2017 season.  He was able to beat the Warriors with the league rules and the bogus refs, that counts as a 3peat or 4 titles in itself: ) Only leading player to defeat a 70 win team ) Only leading player to win game 7 on the road in the competitive modern eras (ie, since the 60s Celtics)  ) Only leading player to come back from 3-1 ) Only player to conquer all statistical categories in the finals ) If nothing else, He brought the city of Cleveland an NBA Championship, ended the curse, and ended the 52 year drought  But individually,  aside from accomplishments, his game evolved to a new level that Jordan never touched.  And his game was so effective and impressive without having to score more than a few baskets... BUT HE STILL PROVED HE CAN GET A 30 POINT TRIPLE DOUBLE ON ANY GIVEN NIGHT. To me, he reached "GOAT" STATUS by the middle of the season, and by the time the finals was over he certianly cemented he was greater than Jordan.  But to me, picking one single player as the best of greatest ever is a farce or myth.  I simply like the idea of Mount Rushmore where the top 5 or 6 are placed for the combination of individual greatness as well as achievements.  Between Jordan and Lebron... Jordan is better because he made it look better Lebron is greater because he made it look easier Kareem is truly THE GOAT, because he dominated way before the NBA and all the way til his retirement, and he was just unstoppable.  His numbers and accomplishments coupled with his physicality are head and shoulders above all else.

GSW were a one hit wonder. Curry did not play ONE SINGLE HEALTHY POINT GUARD in 2015 playoffs, not to mention they avoided BOTH OKC and SA. Then once GSW got to the Finals (after beating Houston LOL) they faced a Kyrie/Love-less Cavs team and won in 6. With something to prove, they treated all 82 regular season games like a Game 7 in 2016, whereas teams like Cleveland, OKC, SA rested players on occasion. GSW went down 3-1 to OKC (after they avoided the LAC who I think would have beat the Warriors, but BG/CP3 both got hurt). I give them huge credit for coming back down in that series from 3-1...but you have to admit that OKC blew that series big time. With free agency coming up it doesn't look like GSW will bring back a few players and I believe Durant is a lock to stay with OKC after that Magic trade that happened last night. I put an asterisk on their title, 73 wins, unanimous MVP (that went 1-6 in 4Q of NBA Finals Game 7), and their organization for thinking they were "light years ahead" of all other organizations in the NBA. I fully expect a LeBron vs OKC/SA series next year in the 2017 NBA Finals.

The Kyrie dagger will eventually go down as one of the top 5 shots in Finals history.  Give it some time for people to truly appreciate it and process the score, the moment, the circumstances, etc.  But that Lebron BLOCK will live on as one of the greatest PLAYS in not only Finals history, but NBA history.  It's season defining, series defining, and quite possibly might be the defining play of Lebron's career when he is done.  Jordan has a solid 5 memorable moments from his career that I can think of.  Im talking when you are given 10 seconds to think of MJ, the images that come to mind.  The Last Shot, "The Shot" vs the Cavs, him bent over clutching his shorts during game 5 of the 97 Finals, of Pip helping him off the court.  Jordan switching hands in mid air vs the Lakers, shrugging his shoulders vs Portland, crying with his dad during his first title, clutching the trophy, on the ground crying in 96 after winning the title on Father's Day in memory of his dad.    The sort of thing.  That block is certain to be at the top of the list for Lebron.

This comment section has this bizarre frequent occurrence where people think that underdog means that you have to have like no chance of winning and still win anyway. But thatâ€™s ridiculous, itâ€™s just a term to compare different teams. Obviously those Cavs werenâ€™t underdogs compared to most teams in the league, and nobody is saying they were. But they were underdogs to the Warriors because the Warriors won way more games, had never lost twice at home all year, had the unanimous MVP and went up 3-1. In that series the Cavs were unquestionably underdogs as compared to the Warriors, and thatâ€™s all that matters here. SAS said they had 0 chance after just game 2. Saying they werenâ€™t underdogs because they had a good chance at winning compared to other teams besides the Warriors is like saying that 9 is not a lesser number than 10 because 9 isnâ€™t as as low as 4. Thatâ€™s not how this works. 9 can be greater than every number below it and STILL be less than 10, just as the Cavs can be one of the best teams in the league and STILL be underdogs compared to the Warriors. Nearly every fan and sports analyst in the country would have picked the Warriors to win that series, so by definition, the Cavs were underdogs in that particular series.  Not underdogs compared to the majority of the league, but still underdogs compared to the Warriors. Anyone who claims otherwise is just speaking nonsense.  Iâ€™m not here to start up an argument or attack people or call people stupid, Iâ€™m just here to say my piece and leave. I appreciate the person here who was admitting that they were being irrational a few years ago, thatâ€™s a mature thing to do and I have no intention of dragging you into another debate, I just want to clarify something for anyone reading this who doesnâ€™t understand what the term underdog means.

Lebron James is the GOAT of this era by far. In 2009 the Cavs made it to the 2nd round of the playoffs. When he left they, had the most consecutive losses in the history of the NBA. Lebron brought the Heat to 4 straight Finals and won 2 of them. He returned to Cleveland and brought them to 2 consecutive Finals and winning one of them against all odds, down 3-1 and defeated a top 5 team in the history of the NBA. I love Jordan but his impact on his team is barely noticeable (they only lost 2 more games without him) which goes to show that Jordan a much better supporting cast than Lebron ever did. Lebron also had alot more on his shoulders. He had to defend, make plays, grab rebounds and score. All Jordan ever had to do was score. Pippen and Rodman are the 2 best defenders ever and Rodman is the best rebounder ever. Im not saying that Lebron is better but im just saying that Jordan is not miles ahead of Lebron like many people seem to think. Both of them are GOATS. Jordan is the GOAT of his era and Lebron is that GOAT for this era.

TupacolypseNow Did Jordan get a triple double in a game 7? No......so then why argue? Both players have done things the other hasn't. LeBron got out of a 3-1 hole. Yeah, well Jordan wouldn't ever get into a 3-1 hole, you say. Well that's all nice, considering Jordan has never won without solid teammates. TupacolypseNow LeBron can definitely talk to Jordan:  -His (rounded) stat line this year was 30-11-9. His rounded stat line last year 36-13-9. He was one (rounded) number down from averaging a triple double two finals in a row. That's absolutely ridiculous.  -The reason I say rounded was because averaging a triple double does not mean you got a triple double every game, I think LeBron only had a triple double 2 or 3 of the games this year, one being game 3 and the other being game 7, though he probably did another game.  -LeBron is the first to be top 10 in playoff points, assists, and rebounds.  -LeBron, if he goes absolutely insane the next couple seasons, has a pretty good chance to have the second or even first highest points in NBA history.  -LeBron is the first person to lead both teams in every stat for an entire finals.  -LeBron did all of this against the greatest team ever (record wise), the greatest three point shooter ever (who also happens to be the first unanimous season MVP ever), the two winningest coaches by percentage in Walton and Kerr (who, though they were role players, were on championship teams with two other greats, namely Jordan and Kobe). He literally had all the odds stacked against him.  -LeBron is the first star to truly live up to the hype. He has been hyped by the media since he was in highschool, and he has not dissapointed.  -LeBron is one of the few stars who has carried absolute garbage teams to the finals, Iverson being another notable one. Jordan could not do that.  -LeBron's kids have way more potential to be great than Jordan's kids ever had, and where are Jordan's kids now?  -Why do I mention LeBron's kids? He is the first star whose kids have a huge chance to become stars in the future. Why? Because he has not put pressure on them to be like him. Bryce James' favorite player is Curry. LeBron Jr.'s fave is Westbrook. This lessens the pressure on his kids to live up to their father's name, which is good, because that means they'll be better off.  -LeBron is the first player who left his hometown team because the organization was trash, became the most hated athlete in America and second only to probably Ronaldo (and Ronaldo deserves hate way more than LeBron), and then returned to win a ring for the former fans that now hated him.  -Let me add this: he won the ring. And it wasn't just any town he won it for. He won it for freaking Cleveland.  -FINALLY: LeBron is the first star to never be caught in a major scandal. Kobe had the rape allegations/relationship troubles. Jordan was addicted to gambling. If social media was like it is now back when they played they would have been destroyed.  LeBron definitely touches Jordan, people always knew he'd be great and he lived up to that. He is closer to being like Jordan than any other player in NBA history. LeBron was never carried in a finals that he won, and he was only carried in one finals that he lost (vs the Mavs).

enter.the.void.II That depends on what you need on your team. By traditional accounts, Draymond Green is the best all around player on the Warriors. He fills so many categories on the statsheet, like Lebron likes to do. Curry's threat of offense opens up so many options and allows the team to work. The Warriors just lost a few crucial pieces along the way at different times during the finals and it culminated and exposed them in game 7.   They got beat on the boards all series. Bogut getting hurt didn't help. Their interior defense suffered, they lost second chance points off tapbacks, they lost their best passing big man. Kerr had to cycle between Festus and Varejao and they were mostly terrible.  Barnes was just horrible. He had to step up on the rebounding and defense with Bogut gone but was mostly a non-factor there and a liability on offense.  Draymond hit Lebron in the balls and got suspended for game 5, the same game where Bogut got hurt.  At the end of the day, they were still a better team on paper and they should have sneaked out 1 more win after 3-1.
